citations.narrative:
The licensee is exhibiting 2 spider monkeys (Group 6 brachiating non-human primates). However, the licensee does not
have a license authorizing the use of Group 6 non-human primates. Failure to obtain a license for special group animals
could negatively impact the welfare of the exhibited animals and the safety of the general public.
Licenses authorize a specific number and specific type(s) of animals for use in regulated activity (i.e., exhibiting). A USDA
license must specifically authorize the use of Group 6 non-human primates, which includes brachiating species of non-
human primates. The licensee must remove the Group 6 non-human primates from exhibition, until a new license is
obtained which authorizes the use of Group 6 non-human primates.
To be corrected from this date of 04 September 2025 forward.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The attending veterinarian was not notified of new hair mats on "Annabelle" an approximately 15-year-old bobcat. The
inspector observed fist-sized hair mats affecting the dorsal coat and stringy hair clumps on the underbelly of Annabelle
during inspection. The facility representative confirmed that they had not spoken with the attending veterinarian
specifically about this condition in Annabelle. The attending veterinarian is generally aware of this type of condition that
has historically affected the bobcats at this facility, but had not been made aware of Annabelle's current condition. There
is no protocol in the program of veterinary care on how to address hair matting in bobcats at the facility. Failure to have a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication on problems of animal health to the attending veterinarian may result in
delayed treatment and/or prolonged discomfort in the animal.
The licensee must convey changes in the health and well-being of animals to the attending veterinarian in a timely
manner to allow for adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by 05 September 2025.

The licensee elects to identify the 10 wolf-dog hybrids with microchips but does not have a microchip reader on hand. Not
having a microchip reader or other acceptable means of identification does not allow the licensee or inspector to
accurately identify the animals; a necessity for carrying out proper husbandry and official APHIS duties.
A class "C'' exhibitor shall identify all live dogs and cats under his or her control or on his or her premises, whether held,
purchased, or otherwise acquired. This can be accomplished by an official USDA sequentially numbered tag that is kept
on the door of the animal's cage or run, or by microchip with a microchip reader on hand. Dogs used for exhibition must
also have a record or documentation which includes the tag number or microchip, a written description of the animal and
photograph.
To be corrected by 26 September 2025.

There is a 6-inch gap under the south access gate of the perimeter fence that faces the main highway. The length of this
perimeter fence is used as miscellaneous storage on the interior portion of the facility. A trailer taller than the perimeter
fence is stored next to the fence and has smaller vehicles stored around it that may act as climbable structures for loose
animals to escape from the facility. Failure to maintain a perimeter fence may result in the escape of loose animals or
bodily injury to animals by persons or animals that can breach the perimeter fence.
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height (8 feet for current animals
on inventory) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the
animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact
with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the
facility.
To be corrected by 01 October 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
A bird showing signs of being in psychological distress through behavior or appearance did not have a written special
considerations section in the avian environment enhancement plan. An eclectus parrot named "Shelby" was observed to
have feather loss and mild scabbing on her upper back. The facility representative stated the animal was under veterinary
care, which included a diet change approved by the attending veterinarian, increased enrichment and a change in
housing. The attending veterinarian attributed the feather picking to be behavior in origin. Failure to document the special
attention protocol for birds showing signs of psychological distress may result in inadequate care and limited resolution of
the condition.
The licensee must include in the avian environmental enhancement plan considerations for birds that need special
attention such as those that show signs of psychological distress through behavior and appearance.
To be corrected by 26 September 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(ii) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee is exhibiting 2 spider monkeys (Group 6 brachiating non-human primates). However, the licensee does not 
have a license authorizing the use of Group 6 non-human primates. Failure to obtain a license for special group animals 
could negatively impact the welfare of the exhibited animals and the safety of the general public. 
 
Licenses authorize a specific number and specific type(s) of animals for use in regulated activity (i.e., exhibiting). A USDA 
license must specifically authorize the use of Group 6 non-human primates, which includes brachiating species of non-
human primates. The licensee must remove the Group 6 non-human primates from exhibition, until a new license is 
obtained which authorizes the use of Group 6 non-human primates. 
 
To be corrected from this date of 04 September 2025 forward. 
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The attending veterinarian was not notified of new hair mats on "Annabelle" an approximately 15-year-old bobcat. The 
inspector observed fist-sized hair mats affecting the dorsal coat and stringy hair clumps on the underbelly of Annabelle 
during inspection. The facility representative confirmed that they had not spoken with the attending veterinarian 
specifically about this condition in Annabelle. The attending veterinarian is generally aware of this type of condition that 
has historically affected the bobcats at this facility, but had not been made aware of Annabelle's current condition. There 
is no protocol in the program of veterinary care on how to address hair matting in bobcats at the facility. Failure to have a 
mechanism of direct and frequent communication on problems of animal health to the attending veterinarian may result in 
delayed treatment and/or prolonged discomfort in the animal.  
 
The licensee must convey changes in the health and well-being of animals to the attending veterinarian in a timely 
manner to allow for adequate veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by 05 September 2025. 
2.50(c)

Time and method of identification. 
The licensee elects to identify the 10 wolf-dog hybrids with microchips but does not have a microchip reader on hand. Not 
having a microchip reader or other acceptable means of identification does not allow the licensee or inspector to 
accurately identify the animals; a necessity for carrying out proper husbandry and official APHIS duties. 
 
A class "C'' exhibitor shall identify all live dogs and cats under his or her control or on his or her premises, whether held, 
purchased, or otherwise acquired. This can be accomplished by an official USDA sequentially numbered tag that is kept 
on the door of the animal's cage or run, or by microchip with a microchip reader on hand. Dogs used for exhibition must 
also have a record or documentation which includes the tag number or microchip, a written description of the animal and 
photograph. 
 
To be corrected by 26 September 2025. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is a 6-inch gap under the south access gate of the perimeter fence that faces the main highway. The length of this 
perimeter fence is used as miscellaneous storage on the interior portion of the facility. A trailer taller than the perimeter 
fence is stored next to the fence and has smaller vehicles stored around it that may act as climbable structures for loose 
animals to escape from the facility. Failure to maintain a perimeter fence may result in the escape of loose animals or 
bodily injury to animals by persons or animals that can breach the perimeter fence. 
 
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height (8 feet for current animals 
on inventory) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the 
animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact 
with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the 
facility.  
 
To be corrected by 01 October 2025. 
3.154(c)(2) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
A bird showing signs of being in psychological distress through behavior or appearance did not have a written special 
considerations section in the avian environment enhancement plan. An eclectus parrot named "Shelby" was observed to 
have feather loss and mild scabbing on her upper back. The facility representative stated the animal was under veterinary 
care, which included a diet change approved by the attending veterinarian, increased enrichment and a change in 
housing. The attending veterinarian attributed the feather picking to be behavior in origin. Failure to document the special 
attention protocol for birds showing signs of psychological distress may result in inadequate care and limited resolution of 
the condition.  
 
The licensee must include in the avian environmental enhancement plan considerations for birds that need special 
attention such as those that show signs of psychological distress through behavior and appearance.

To be corrected by 26 September 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
